Kenneth Stanley wrote:

>Colin, one problem with your meta-search for the right mutation
>parameters is that it is likely if you find anything at all it will be
>domain-specific.  The fitness landscape ruggedness, hilliness,
>deceptiveness, etc., in different domains is likely to be different.
>  
>
I agree, and if this is the case we can then look at the numbers that 
come out of each domain and build up a sort of lookup table that we can 
refer to whenever we approach a new domain. Now it might be that all of 
the numbers come out approximately the same for each domain, or we might 
not find any specific parameters for any domain - due to the large 
amount of noise. Whatever happens we will have learned something.

>Therefore, it actually kind of makes sense if you want to search for
>mutation parameters to tie them to the individual genes, since at
>least then the search is domain-specific.  Of course, as you point
>out, this kind of gene-by-gene searching may go all over the place,
>but then again, at least in the ES community (as Ian pointed out),
>they have had some success with this, and it's (I think) almost a
>standard part of their methodology now.
>  
>
It seems very likely to me that the genome or gene level meta-parameters 
will drift a *lot*, mainly because there isn't much selection pressure 
being applied to them - the pressure is applied whenever a new better 
genome is found, and we can say aha! the set of meta-params on this 
genome/gene must be good. But of course a bad set of meta-params can 
find good genomes to, sometimes.  Assuming a lot of drift you then have 
to consider the possibility that some of these drifting parameters 
aren't working very well, but they are still able to propagate through 
the population (because of low selection pressure) and in fact you might 
end up with a population where only a few of the genomes are actually 
using sensible meta-parameters that have any chance of finding a good 
solution.

No doubt then the ES people have encountered these issues, so some 
reading would be in order before implementing such a system with NEAT.

>There actually is a third, more sophisticated method for getting
>weight mutation parameters, which is to measure the success of
>mutations in various directions in the multidimensional space and
>actually construct a model of the most promising mutation trajectory
>based on the experience over past generations (as a multi-dimensional
>probability distribution).  That has recently popped up in ES as well,
>though the math behind it is not simple at all.  
>  
>
Ahh ok, I definitely think this could help compensate for the lack of 
selection pressure. You still might get misleading signals, but they 
would be averaged out by maintaining some central model that keeps track 
of all beneficial and detrimental meta-params.

>The problem of getting weight mutation right is a little bit of an art
>form and may have an element of alchemy (i.e. there's perhaps not that
>much you can really do without just getting lucky) but then again
>there probably are some ranges that are more reasonable than others
>over multiple domains, so it's not bad to learn more about it.
>  
>
This is my general philosophy for now. It may be simplistic compared to 
the techniques discussed in the last couple of days, but at least if 
it's not a step forward in searching efficiency, it will be a step 
forward in terms of knowledge.

Colin
